elements.content: A pair of metal phosphonates, {[(CH3)2NH2]­[Zn2(HEDP)­(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]·H2O} (1) and {[CH3NH3]­[Zn2(HEDP)­(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]·3.5H2O} (2) (HEDP = 1-hydroxyethylidene diphosphonate, H2BPDC = biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid), have been successfully synthesized by virtue of a dual-ligand strategy. The Zn­(II) centers in both 1 and 2 are bridged by the −PO3 units of HEDP to form 2D inorganic–organic hybrid layers. Adjacent Zn–HEDP layers are further pillared and connected by linear O-containing linkers to furnish 3D pillared-layer architectures showing a (3,4)-connected network. Solid-state photoluminescence studies of compounds 1 and 2 have been performed, displaying intense emissions at 335 and 340 nm under UV light irradiation, respectively. Moreover, luminescence sensing experiments suggest that compound 1 exhibits a great selectivity and sensitivity for detection of Cu2+/Fe3+, IO4 –/Cr2O7 2– and nitrobenzene, which could be considered as a promising multiple sensor in an aqueous system.
elements.clean_text: A pair of metal phosphonates, {[(CH3)2NH2][Zn2(HEDP)(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]⋅H2O} (1) and {[CH3NH3][Zn2(HEDP)(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3.5H2O} (2) (HEDP = 1-hydroxyethylidene diphosphonate, H2BPDC = biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid), have been successfully synthesized by virtue of a dual-ligand strategy. The Zn(II) centers in both 1 and 2 are bridged by the -PO3 units of HEDP to form 2D inorganic-organic hybrid layers. Adjacent Zn-HEDP layers are further pillared and connected by linear O-containing linkers to furnish 3D pillared-layer architectures showing a (3,4)-connected network. Solid-state photoluminescence studies of compounds 1 and 2 have been performed, displaying intense emissions at 335 and 340 nm under UV light irradiation, respectively. Moreover, luminescence sensing experiments suggest that compound 1 exhibits a great selectivity and sensitivity for detection of Cu2+/Fe3+, IO4 -/Cr2O7 2- and nitrobenzene, which could be considered as a promising multiple sensor in an aqueous system.

elements.content:
Two pillared-layer metal phosphonates have been successfully constructed, exhibiting luminescent sensing of Cu2+/Fe3+, IO4 −/Cr2O7 2−, and nitrobenzene.

Introduction

As a class of inorganic–organic hybrids, metal phosphonates represent a particularly important field due to not only their diverse architectures but also promising properties as functional materials in the domains of photochemistry, catalysis, ion exchange, molecular magnetism, proton conductivity, and so on. Generally, the desirable solids fabricated by diverse phosphonates and various metal centers (main groups, transition metals, lanthanide ions, etc.) could be equipped with several interesting merits: (a) the phosphonate molecules with multiple potential coordination sites enable them to bridge several metal centers via diverse coordination modes; (b) the phosphate groups could adopt various fashions such as neutral or anionic forms according to the pH values of the reaction system; (c) the targeted metal–phosphonate materials are usually robust and stable in air or water which could thus be considered as a significant advantage over other coordination polymers (CPs) in terms of practical application. Numerous efforts have been continuously made on the assembly of versatile metal phosphonates, leading to an important generation of crystal engineering. For instance, by employing a tetravalent zirconium ion as the metal node, Wang et al. prepared a series of water-stable Zr–phosphonates which display high permanent porosity and exhibit excellent uranium uptake capabilities. The porphyrin-based tetraphosphonic acid was used to assist the generation of thermally and chemically stable metal–organic frameworks with proton conduction properties. Zheng and co-workers reported a decanuclear dysprosium phosphonate, showing an interestingly reversible on–off switching of single-molecule-magnetism behavior. In a word, the investigation of metal phosphonates with fascinating structures accompanied by excellent physicochemical properties is still a hot topic and remains popular.
elements.clean_text:
Two pillared-layer metal phosphonates have been successfully constructed, exhibiting luminescent sensing of Cu2+/Fe3+, IO4 -/Cr2O7 2-, and nitrobenzene.

Introduction

As a class of inorganic-organic hybrids, metal phosphonates represent a particularly important field due to not only their diverse architectures but also promising properties as functional materials in the domains of photochemistry, catalysis, ion exchange, molecular magnetism, proton conductivity, and so on. Generally, the desirable solids fabricated by diverse phosphonates and various metal centers (main groups, transition metals, lanthanide ions, etc.) could be equipped with several interesting merits: (a) the phosphonate molecules with multiple potential coordination sites enable them to bridge several metal centers via diverse coordination modes; (b) the phosphate groups could adopt various fashions such as neutral or anionic forms according to the pH values of the reaction system; (c) the targeted metal-phosphonate materials are usually robust and stable in air or water which could thus be considered as a significant advantage over other coordination polymers (CPs) in terms of practical application. Numerous efforts have been continuously made on the assembly of versatile metal phosphonates, leading to an important generation of crystal engineering. For instance, by employing a tetravalent zirconium ion as the metal node, Wang et al. prepared a series of water-stable Zr-phosphonates which display high permanent porosity and exhibit excellent uranium uptake capabilities. The porphyrin-based tetraphosphonic acid was used to assist the generation of thermally and chemically stable metal-organic frameworks with proton conduction properties. Zheng and co-workers reported a decanuclear dysprosium phosphonate, showing an interestingly reversible on-off switching of single-molecule-magnetism behavior. In a word, the investigation of metal phosphonates with fascinating structures accompanied by excellent physicochemical properties is still a hot topic and remains popular.

elements.content: A review of the reported literature on metal–phosphonate systems reveals that novel architectures may be expected through the introduction of diverse ionic guest organic molecules as the templates or various organic linkers with different types and shapes as the auxiliary ligands during the assembly process. With regard to the latter which is called the dual-ligand strategy, N-containing molecules such as pyridine, imidazole, triazine, and triazole together with their derivatives are of particular interest in serving as the second building moieties to contribute to the acquisition of final metal phosphonate products. As the π-conjugated nitrogen-based ligands are usually regarded as electron acceptors once they are coordinated to various metal centers, and the phosphonate subunits could serve as the electron donors, therefore a combination of these two different parts could give rise to a great number of optimized photochromic hybrid materials. Our group has made many efforts toward the construction of crystalline photochromic materials through the marriage of a pyridine derivative unit and a Zn–phosphonate followed by a ligand to ligand charge transfer (LLCT) mechanism. In addition, it has been widely acknowledged that polycarboxylate ligands with multiple bridging modes through coordinated O atoms are great choices to act as the coligands for the generation of intriguing networks. As a result, a large number of CPs possessing captivating architectures and attractive properties have thus been successfully constructed, which may be good candidates as functional hybrids in optics, electrics, and magnetics. However, there have been relatively fewer investigations of metal phosphonates with incorporated O-donor linkers in comparison with the extensively reported pyridine- or azole-based metal–phosphonate systems, thus much more attention should be paid to the former systems.
elements.clean_text: A review of the reported literature on metal-phosphonate systems reveals that novel architectures may be expected through the introduction of diverse ionic guest organic molecules as the templates or various organic linkers with different types and shapes as the auxiliary ligands during the assembly process. With regard to the latter which is called the dual-ligand strategy, N-containing molecules such as pyridine, imidazole, triazine, and triazole together with their derivatives are of particular interest in serving as the second building moieties to contribute to the acquisition of final metal phosphonate products. As the π-conjugated nitrogen-based ligands are usually regarded as electron acceptors once they are coordinated to various metal centers, and the phosphonate subunits could serve as the electron donors, therefore a combination of these two different parts could give rise to a great number of optimized photochromic hybrid materials. Our group has made many efforts toward the construction of crystalline photochromic materials through the marriage of a pyridine derivative unit and a Zn-phosphonate followed by a ligand to ligand charge transfer (LLCT) mechanism. In addition, it has been widely acknowledged that polycarboxylate ligands with multiple bridging modes through coordinated O atoms are great choices to act as the coligands for the generation of intriguing networks. As a result, a large number of CPs possessing captivating architectures and attractive properties have thus been successfully constructed, which may be good candidates as functional hybrids in optics, electrics, and magnetics. However, there have been relatively fewer investigations of metal phosphonates with incorporated O-donor linkers in comparison with the extensively reported pyridine- or azole-based metal-phosphonate systems, thus much more attention should be paid to the former systems.

elements.content: As part of our continuous work on metal phosphonates, we are employing the possibility to introduce polycarboxylate linkers into a metal–1-hydroxyethylidenediphosphonate (HEDP) system to hunt for new functional crystalline materials on the basis of the following considerations: (a) the HEDP could adopt different chelating-bridging modes, thus resulting in diverse networks, (b) the π-conjugated O-donor ligands could endow the final targets with good photoluminescence performance, and (c) the high stability and rich host–guest chemistry of metal phosphonates make them an ideal platform as a chemical sensor. Herein, we report two isostructural Zn–phosphonates, {[(CH3)2NH2]­[Zn2(HEDP)­(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]·H2O} (1) and {[CH3NH3]­[Zn2(HEDP)­(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]·3.5H2O} (2) (H2BPDC = biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid) with BPDC as the auxiliary ligands. The linkage of Zn­(II) and HEDP first generates a 2D layered network, and these neighboring layers are further linked through the linear O-containing ligands which act as the pillars, giving rise to a final 3D framework. The luminescent properties of both compounds were investigated. Moreover, luminescent sensing experiments indicate that 1 can act as a multiple sensor toward different ions and solvents.
elements.clean_text: As part of our continuous work on metal phosphonates, we are employing the possibility to introduce polycarboxylate linkers into a metal-1-hydroxyethylidenediphosphonate (HEDP) system to hunt for new functional crystalline materials on the basis of the following considerations: (a) the HEDP could adopt different chelating-bridging modes, thus resulting in diverse networks, (b) the π-conjugated O-donor ligands could endow the final targets with good photoluminescence performance, and (c) the high stability and rich host-guest chemistry of metal phosphonates make them an ideal platform as a chemical sensor. Herein, we report two isostructural Zn-phosphonates, {[(CH3)2NH2][Zn2(HEDP)(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]⋅H2O} (1) and {[CH3NH3][Zn2(HEDP)(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3.5H2O} (2) (H2BPDC = biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid) with BPDC as the auxiliary ligands. The linkage of Zn(II) and HEDP first generates a 2D layered network, and these neighboring layers are further linked through the linear O-containing ligands which act as the pillars, giving rise to a final 3D framework. The luminescent properties of both compounds were investigated. Moreover, luminescent sensing experiments indicate that 1 can act as a multiple sensor toward different ions and solvents.

elements.content: All reagents have been purchased and used without further purification. With the help of a Philips X’Pert-MPD diffractometer equipped with a Cu-target tube, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) spectroscopy has been performed. Elemental analysis data for C,H,N were collected from a PerkinElmer 240C analyzer. By employing a MAGNA-560 FT-IR spectrometer, we have carried out IR spectroscopy. With a FLS920 spectrophotometer, the photoluminescence spectra could be obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All reagents have been purchased and used without further purification. With the help of a Philips X'Pert-MPD diffractometer equipped with a Cu-target tube, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) spectroscopy has been performed. Elemental analysis data for C,H,N were collected from a PerkinElmer 240C analyzer. By employing a MAGNA-560 FT-IR spectrometer, we have carried out IR spectroscopy. With a FLS920 spectrophotometer, the photoluminescence spectra could be obtained.

elements.content: A 0.16 g portion of ZnO (1.0 mmol), 0.12 g of H2BPDC (0.5 mmol), 0.2 mL of HEDP (1.6 mmol), 0.2 mL of HF, 5 mL of H2O, and 5 mL of DMF were mixed in a Teflon-lined autoclave with a volume of 20 mL, and then the contents were heated and kept at 145 °C for 1 week. As the temperature was decreased to 30 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min, colorless X-ray-quality crystals could be acquired in 58% yield based on H2BPDC. Anal. Calcd for C11H22NO12P2Zn2 (552.97): C, 23.89; H, 4.01; N, 2.53. Found: C, 23.98; H, 4.06; N, 2.64. IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3386 (s), 3050 (s), 2797 (s), 2493 (m), 1600 (s), 1539 (m), 1401 (s), 1108 (s), 990 (s), 935 (m), 812 (w), 764 (m), 675 (w) (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[(CH3)2NH2][Zn2(HEDP)(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]⋅H2O} (1)

A 0.16 g portion of ZnO (1.0 mmol), 0.12 g of H2BPDC (0.5 mmol), 0.2 mL of HEDP (1.6 mmol), 0.2 mL of HF, 5 mL of H2O, and 5 mL of DMF were mixed in a Teflon-lined autoclave with a volume of 20 mL, and then the contents were heated and kept at 145 °C for 1 week. As the temperature was decreased to 30 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min, colorless X-ray-quality crystals could be acquired in 58% yield based on H2BPDC. Anal. Calcd for C11H22NO12P2Zn2 (552.97): C, 23.89; H, 4.01; N, 2.53. Found: C, 23.98; H, 4.06; N, 2.64. IR (KBr pellets, cm-1): 3386 (s), 3050 (s), 2797 (s), 2493 (m), 1600 (s), 1539 (m), 1401 (s), 1108 (s), 990 (s), 935 (m), 812 (w), 764 (m), 675 (w) (Figure S2).

elements.content: A mixture of 0.16 g of ZnO (1.0 mmol), 0.12 g of H2BPDC (0.5 mmol), 0.15 mL of HEDP (1.2 mmol), 0.2 mL of HF, 10 mL of H2O, and 0.8 mL of methylamine was placed and sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave. The contents were heated to 80 °C, kept at that temperature for 1 week, and cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min, giving colorless block crystals. Yield: ca. 38% based on H2BPDC. Anal. Calcd for C10H25NO14.5P2Zn2 (583.99): C, 20.56; H, 4.31; N, 2.40. Found: C, 20.63; H, 4.19; N, 2.31. IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3394 (m), 2974 (m), 2878 (w), 1594 (s), 1416 (m), 1092 (s), 996 (w), 948 (w), 778 (w), 675 (w).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[CH3NH3][Zn2(HEDP)(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3.5H2O} (2)

A mixture of 0.16 g of ZnO (1.0 mmol), 0.12 g of H2BPDC (0.5 mmol), 0.15 mL of HEDP (1.2 mmol), 0.2 mL of HF, 10 mL of H2O, and 0.8 mL of methylamine was placed and sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave. The contents were heated to 80 °C, kept at that temperature for 1 week, and cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min, giving colorless block crystals. Yield: ca. 38% based on H2BPDC. Anal. Calcd for C10H25NO14.5P2Zn2 (583.99): C, 20.56; H, 4.31; N, 2.40. Found: C, 20.63; H, 4.19; N, 2.31. IR (KBr pellets, cm-1): 3394 (m), 2974 (m), 2878 (w), 1594 (s), 1416 (m), 1092 (s), 996 (w), 948 (w), 778 (w), 675 (w).

elements.content: Data collection for the two compounds was performed by employing an XtaLAB-mini diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation) at room temperature. The structures of 1 and 2 were solved and refined with the help of the SHELX-2016 software. Some highly disordered guest water molecules which could not be determined in 1 and 2 have been treated with the “SQUEEZE” procedure. summarizes the detailed data for the structures of 1 and 2. Tables S1 and S2 give some selected bond lengths and angles for the two compounds. CCDC numbers 1917761 and 1917762 correspond to 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement

Data collection for the two compounds was performed by employing an XtaLAB-mini diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation) at room temperature. The structures of 1 and 2 were solved and refined with the help of the SHELX-2016 software. Some highly disordered guest water molecules which could not be determined in 1 and 2 have been treated with the "SQUEEZE" procedure.  summarizes the detailed data for the structures of 1 and 2. Tables S1 and S2 give some selected bond lengths and angles for the two compounds. CCDC numbers 1917761 and 1917762 correspond to 1 and 2.

elements.content:
Crystal and Refinement Data for Solids <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold> 1 2 formula C11H22NO12P2Zn2 C10H25NO14.5P2Zn2 M r (g mol–1) 552.97 583.99 space group P21/c P21/c cryst syst monoclinic monoclinic a (Å) 6.4327(10) 6.4394(6) b (Å) 30.2492(5) 28.798(3) c (Å) 11.7675(2) 11.7113(11) α (deg) 90 90 β (deg) 104.818(2) 104.643(8) γ (deg) 90 90 V (Å3) 2213.62(7) 2101.2(4) Z 4 4 F(000) 1124 1192 Dc (gcm–3) 1.659 1.846 μ (mm–1) 4.547 2.505 R int 0.0612 0.0459 no. of collected rflns 81882 6935 no. of unique rflns 4488 3704 GOF on F 2 0.980 0.964 R1, wR2 (I > 2σ(I)) 0.0689, 0.1944 0.0546, 0.1323 R1, wR2 (all data) 0.0692, 0.1946 0.0787, 0.1436

R1 = ∑||F o| – |F c||/∑|F o|.

wR2 = {∑[w(F o 2 – F c 2)2]/∑w(F o 2)2}1/2.

Compounds 1 and 2 both belong to the monoclinic P21/c space group and show isostructural architectures according to a single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Herein, only the structure of 1 is discussed and depicted for clarity. In its asymmetric unit, there are a pair of Zn­(II) ions, one HEDP molecule, half of a completely deprotonated BPDC ligand, a pair of coordinated water molecules, one dimethylamine counterion, and one lattice water molecule. Though both Zn1 and Zn2 ions together with their surroundings adopt the octahedral [ZnO6] geometry, their coordination fashions are not same. As depicted in a, the Zn1 center connects with four phosphonate oxygen atoms from three symmetry-related HEDP moieties, one carboxylic oxygen atom from a deprotonated BPDC molecule, and one terminal coordinated water molecule. Differently, the Zn2 ion is coordinated by three phosphonate-O atoms and one hydroxyl-O atom of two HEDP molecules, one carboxylic-O atom of BPDC, and one water molecule. The HEDP ligand in 1 adopts a μ4-η2:η2:η1:η1:η1:η1:η0 tetradentate connection fashion to bridge/chelate four metal centers to generate a [Zn2(HEDP)3] building unit with a Zn1···Zn2 distance of 3.09 Å (b). The Zn-based dinuclear cluster is further extended through the −PO3 groups from HEDP to result in 2D Zn–HEDP layers, which contain the four-membered and six-membered rings as depicted in c. The inorganic–organic layers are packed in an −ABAB– fashion, and the remaining coordination sites of metal centers are completely filled by carboxyl groups from BPDC pillars, leading to a 3D pillared-layer framework with a Zn···Zn distance between adjacent layers of 15.15 Å (d). The 1D channel with a dimension of 11.38 × 15.15 Å2 could be observed along the a axis direction, which is occupied by dimethylamine cations formed from the in situ hydrolysis of DMF. From the viewpoint of topology, the HEDP molecule and [Zn2(HEDP)3] moiety can be treated as three- and four-connected nodes, respectively, and BPDC units could be regarded as the linkers. Therefore the whole network could be viewed as a 2-nodal (3,4)-connected network (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structures of {[(CH3)2NH2][Zn2(HEDP)(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]⋅H2O} (1) and {[CH3NH3][Zn2(HEDP)(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3.5H2O} (2)

Compounds 1 and 2 both belong to the monoclinic P21/c space group and show isostructural architectures according to a single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Herein, only the structure of 1 is discussed and depicted for clarity. In its asymmetric unit, there are a pair of Zn(II) ions, one HEDP molecule, half of a completely deprotonated BPDC ligand, a pair of coordinated water molecules, one dimethylamine counterion, and one lattice water molecule. Though both Zn1 and Zn2 ions together with their surroundings adopt the octahedral [ZnO6] geometry, their coordination fashions are not same. As depicted in a, the Zn1 center connects with four phosphonate oxygen atoms from three symmetry-related HEDP moieties, one carboxylic oxygen atom from a deprotonated BPDC molecule, and one terminal coordinated water molecule. Differently, the Zn2 ion is coordinated by three phosphonate-O atoms and one hydroxyl-O atom of two HEDP molecules, one carboxylic-O atom of BPDC, and one water molecule. The HEDP ligand in 1 adopts a μ4-η2:η2:η1:η1:η1:η1:η0 tetradentate connection fashion to bridge/chelate four metal centers to generate a [Zn2(HEDP)3] building unit with a Zn1⋅⋅⋅Zn2 distance of 3.09 Å (b). The Zn-based dinuclear cluster is further extended through the -PO3 groups from HEDP to result in 2D Zn-HEDP layers, which contain the four-membered and six-membered rings as depicted in c. The inorganic-organic layers are packed in an -ABAB- fashion, and the remaining coordination sites of metal centers are completely filled by carboxyl groups from BPDC pillars, leading to a 3D pillared-layer framework with a Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance between adjacent layers of 15.15 Å (d). The 1D channel with a dimension of 11.38 × 15.15 Å2 could be observed along the a axis direction, which is occupied by dimethylamine cations formed from the in situ hydrolysis of DMF. From the viewpoint of topology, the HEDP molecule and [Zn2(HEDP)3] moiety can be treated as three- and four-connected nodes, respectively, and BPDC units could be regarded as the linkers. Therefore the whole network could be viewed as a 2-nodal (3,4)-connected network (Figure S1).

elements.content: (a) Environment of the Zn2+ center. (b) View of the dinuclear SBUs. (c) 2D layer network of 1. (d) 3D pillared-layer framework.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Environment of the Zn2+ center. (b) View of the dinuclear SBUs. (c) 2D layer network of 1. (d) 3D pillared-layer framework.

elements.content: Metal phosphonates fabricated from transition-metal ions containing a d10 configuration and conjugated organic linkers are considered to be potential optical materials and versatile chemical sensors. Therefore, the solid-state luminescence properties of the two compounds and HEDP as well as the H2BPDC ligands were studied at ambient temperature. The free diphosphonate molecule exhibits a fluorescence emission band centered at 360 nm upon excitation with UV light (λex = 320 nm, Figure S3). As displayed in a and Figure S4, the free H2BPDC ligand shows a blue emission centered at 400 nm with 340 nm radiation, which is probably assigned to the electron transition from π* to π or π* to n. For solids 1 and 2, upon excitation with 300 nm UV light, the maximum emission peaks at 335 and 340 nm for 1 and 2 could be readily found, respectively. According to previous studies, we can speculate that the emissions for the two compounds can be ascribed to neither ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) nor to metal to ligand charge transfer (MLCT) in nature. This result indicates that intraligand emissions are responsible for the photoluminescence of these compounds, corresponding to other Zn­(II) compounds with O-donor building linkers.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

Metal phosphonates fabricated from transition-metal ions containing a d10 configuration and conjugated organic linkers are considered to be potential optical materials and versatile chemical sensors. Therefore, the solid-state luminescence properties of the two compounds and HEDP as well as the H2BPDC ligands were studied at ambient temperature. The free diphosphonate molecule exhibits a fluorescence emission band centered at 360 nm upon excitation with UV light (λex = 320 nm, Figure S3). As displayed in a and Figure S4, the free H2BPDC ligand shows a blue emission centered at 400 nm with 340 nm radiation, which is probably assigned to the electron transition from π* to π or π* to n. For solids 1 and 2, upon excitation with 300 nm UV light, the maximum emission peaks at 335 and 340 nm for 1 and 2 could be readily found, respectively. According to previous studies, we can speculate that the emissions for the two compounds can be ascribed to neither ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) nor to metal to ligand charge transfer (MLCT) in nature. This result indicates that intraligand emissions are responsible for the photoluminescence of these compounds, corresponding to other Zn(II) compounds with O-donor building linkers.

elements.content: (a) Solid-state emission spectra for H2BPDC, 1, and 2. (b) Luminescence intensity of 1 in aqueous solution containing various metal ions. (c, d) Emission spectra of an aqueous solution of 1 with various amounts of Cu2+ and Fe3+, respectively. Inset: S–V plot for Cu2+ and Fe3+.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Solid-state emission spectra for H2BPDC, 1, and 2. (b) Luminescence intensity of 1 in aqueous solution containing various metal ions. (c, d) Emission spectra of an aqueous solution of 1 with various amounts of Cu2+ and Fe3+, respectively. Inset: S-V plot for Cu2+ and Fe3+.

elements.content: By virtue of its good photoluminescence performance as well as high water stability, solid 1 was chosen to investigate its sensing properties toward different exotic species. First, to conduct the sensing experiments for metal ions, 5 mg as-synthesized samples of 1 were ground and immersed in 5 mL aqueous solutions of M­(NO3) x (1 mmol L–1; M = Li+, Na+, K+, Cu2+, Co2+, Cd2+, Ni2+, Fe3+, respectively) for 1 h to form M n+@1, and the photoluminescence emission spectrum was then performed. It can be found that the luminescent intensity of 1 is dependent on the nature of the metal ions, especially for Cu2+ and Fe3+, which exhibit an obvious turn-off luminescent quenching effect toward 1 (b).
elements.clean_text:
Detection of Ions

By virtue of its good photoluminescence performance as well as high water stability, solid 1 was chosen to investigate its sensing properties toward different exotic species. First, to conduct the sensing experiments for metal ions, 5 mg as-synthesized samples of 1 were ground and immersed in 5 mL aqueous solutions of M(NO3) x  (1 mmol L-1; M = Li+, Na+, K+, Cu2+, Co2+, Cd2+, Ni2+, Fe3+, respectively) for 1 h to form M n+@1, and the photoluminescence emission spectrum was then performed. It can be found that the luminescent intensity of 1 is dependent on the nature of the metal ions, especially for Cu2+ and Fe3+, which exhibit an obvious turn-off luminescent quenching effect toward 1 (b).

elements.content: To further explore the sensing sensitivity of 1 to Cu2+ and Fe3+, a concentration gradient experiment was carried out with Cu2+ and Fe3+ concentrations ranging from 0 to 0.8 and 0.4 mM, respectively. As displayed in c,d, the luminescence intensity gradually decreased with an increase in Fe3+/Cu2+ concentration. For Cu2+, as the concentration increased to 100 μM, about half of the emission intensity decreased. When the content of Cu2+ reached 800 μM, the luminescence quenching efficiency was up to almost 80%. In addition, the samples of 1 also exhibited sensitive detection performance toward Fe3+. About 50% of the luminescence intensity was reduced with an increase in Fe3+ concentration to 100 μM. When the amount reached 400 μM, the emission intensity decreased by almost 80%. Moreover, the quenching efficiency (K sv) could be quantitatively calculated using the Stern–Volmer equation, I 0/I = 1 + K sv[M], where I 0 and I represent the emission intensities of the blank sample and M n+@1, respectively, and [M] corresponds to the concentration. K sv can be calculated from the slope values in the inset of to be 4.74 × 103 M–1 for Cu2+ and 7.31 × 103 M–1 for Fe3+, respectively, demonstrating obvious luminescent quenching on these two metal ions. To investigate the quenching mechanism, PXRD patterns of compound 1 after sensing tests were measured, which are in good agreement with the as-synthesized 1, suggesting that the host skeleton remains unchanged after immersion in aqueous solutions containing different metal ions (Figure S5). In addition to that, there is no obvious competitive adsorption between Cu2+/Fe3+ and the framework (Figure S7a). Thus, the quenching effect could be a result of an electron transfer process. Both Cu2+ and Fe3+ have unsaturated electronic states of the outer layers, which may act as excellent acceptors of excited electrons. When Cu2+ or Fe3+ is interacts with the framework of 1, electron transfer from the organic ligands to metal ions may occur, which results in a decrease in luminescence intensity.
elements.clean_text: To further explore the sensing sensitivity of 1 to Cu2+ and Fe3+, a concentration gradient experiment was carried out with Cu2+ and Fe3+ concentrations ranging from 0 to 0.8 and 0.4 mM, respectively. As displayed in c,d, the luminescence intensity gradually decreased with an increase in Fe3+/Cu2+ concentration. For Cu2+, as the concentration increased to 100 μM, about half of the emission intensity decreased. When the content of Cu2+ reached 800 μM, the luminescence quenching efficiency was up to almost 80%. In addition, the samples of 1 also exhibited sensitive detection performance toward Fe3+. About 50% of the luminescence intensity was reduced with an increase in Fe3+ concentration to 100 μM. When the amount reached 400 μM, the emission intensity decreased by almost 80%. Moreover, the quenching efficiency (K sv) could be quantitatively calculated using the Stern-Volmer equation, I 0/I = 1 + K sv[M], where I 0 and I represent the emission intensities of the blank sample and M n+@1, respectively, and [M] corresponds to the concentration. K sv can be calculated from the slope values in the inset of  to be 4.74 × 103 M-1 for Cu2+ and 7.31 × 103 M-1 for Fe3+, respectively, demonstrating obvious luminescent quenching on these two metal ions. To investigate the quenching mechanism, PXRD patterns of compound 1 after sensing tests were measured, which are in good agreement with the as-synthesized 1, suggesting that the host skeleton remains unchanged after immersion in aqueous solutions containing different metal ions (Figure S5). In addition to that, there is no obvious competitive adsorption between Cu2+/Fe3+ and the framework (Figure S7a). Thus, the quenching effect could be a result of an electron transfer process. Both Cu2+ and Fe3+ have unsaturated electronic states of the outer layers, which may act as excellent acceptors of excited electrons. When Cu2+ or Fe3+ is interacts with the framework of 1, electron transfer from the organic ligands to metal ions may occur, which results in a decrease in luminescence intensity.

elements.content: Additionally, we have also investigated the detection performance of 1 toward various anions. A 5 mg sample of 1 was dispersed in NaX aqueous solution (X = Br–, I–, SCN–, NO3 –, ClO4 –, BrO3 –, IO4 –, CO3 2–, S2O8 2–, Cr2O7 2–) to generate a suspension (1 × 10–3 M), and the luminescence spectra were then recorded with 300 nm excitation wavelength for all cases. As displayed in , it is clearly found that most anions exert negligible or only minor influence on the luminescence intensity except for IO4 – and Cr2O7 2– anions. The sensitization of the luminescence quenching of 1 toward these two anions was further studied. It is shown in that the luminescence intensities of 1 decreased rapidly upon increasing the concentration of IO4 – ions. As the concentration finally reached 400 μM, more than 70% of the luminescence intensity could be quenched. For Cr2O7 2–, the luminescence of 1 was gradually weakened with increasing concentrations of Cr2O7 2– and could be completely quenched with a low concentration of 40 μM. The K sv values for IO4 – and Cr2O7 2– are 4.44 × 103 and 2.09 × 105 M–1, respectively. It is worth mentioning that the detection ability of 1 is much greater than those of previously reported MOF/CP sensors toward Cr2O7 2–, such as Eu3+@MIL-124 (K sv = 6.034 × 104 M–1), [Zn­(L5)­(BBI)·2H2O] (K sv = 1.168 × 104 M–1). and [Cd­(IPA)­(L6)] n (K sv = 1.168 × 104 M–1). The large K sv value suggests that compound 1 has a high sensitivity for the detection of trace Cr2O7 2–. The PXRD patterns of 1 after treatment with IO4 – and Cr2O7 2– were identical with the simulated pattern, implying that the structure did not collapse (Figure S6). The absorption spectrum of IO4 –/Cr2O7 2– displays intense absorption bands in the ranges of 200–270 and 230–310/310–400 nm (Figure S7b), showing a large overlap with the excitation band of 1, which is responsible for the quenching phenomenon.
elements.clean_text: Additionally, we have also investigated the detection performance of 1 toward various anions. A 5 mg sample of 1 was dispersed in NaX aqueous solution (X = Br-, I-, SCN-, NO3 -, ClO4 -, BrO3 -, IO4 -, CO3 2-, S2O8 2-, Cr2O7 2-) to generate a suspension (1 × 10-3 M), and the luminescence spectra were then recorded with 300 nm excitation wavelength for all cases. As displayed in , it is clearly found that most anions exert negligible or only minor influence on the luminescence intensity except for IO4 - and Cr2O7 2- anions. The sensitization of the luminescence quenching of 1 toward these two anions was further studied. It is shown in  that the luminescence intensities of 1 decreased rapidly upon increasing the concentration of IO4 - ions. As the concentration finally reached 400 μM, more than 70% of the luminescence intensity could be quenched. For Cr2O7 2-, the luminescence of 1 was gradually weakened with increasing concentrations of Cr2O7 2- and could be completely quenched with a low concentration of 40 μM. The K sv values for IO4 - and Cr2O7 2- are 4.44 × 103 and 2.09 × 105 M-1, respectively. It is worth mentioning that the detection ability of 1 is much greater than those of previously reported MOF/CP sensors toward Cr2O7 2-, such as Eu3+@MIL-124 (K sv = 6.034 × 104 M-1), [Zn(L5)(BBI)⋅2H2O] (K sv = 1.168 × 104 M-1). and [Cd(IPA)(L6)] n  (K sv = 1.168 × 104 M-1). The large K sv value suggests that compound 1 has a high sensitivity for the detection of trace Cr2O7 2-. The PXRD patterns of 1 after treatment with IO4 - and Cr2O7 2- were identical with the simulated pattern, implying that the structure did not collapse (Figure S6). The absorption spectrum of IO4 -/Cr2O7 2- displays intense absorption bands in the ranges of 200-270 and 230-310/310-400 nm (Figure S7b), showing a large overlap with the excitation band of 1, which is responsible for the quenching phenomenon.

elements.content: Moreover, the sensing potential of 1 for different solvents was further explored. Various solvents including acetonitrile (CH3CN), N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), cyclohexane, N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), tetrahydrofuran (THF), methylbenzene, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), trichloromethane (CH3Cl), and nitrobenzene (NB) were used as the investigated reagents. The luminescence intensity of 1 is greatly dependent on the organic solvent, especially for NB, which appears as a significant species for luminescence quenching (a). Furthermore, the luminescence intensities were measured by the addition of NB into a suspension of 1 (dispersing 5 mg of 1 into 5 mL of water) to investigate the quenching effect of NB. As shown in b, with an increase in NB concentration from 0 to 0.6 ppm, the emission intensity of 1@aqueous solution decreases sharply with an emission color from bright blue to nearly black under UV light, which implies that compound 1 could act as an efficient luminescent sensor for NB. Decorated by an electron-withdrawing substituent −NO2 group, NB with a low LUMO energy is an excellent electron acceptor, which might drive the electrons from the ligand to the guest species, resulting in the luminescence quenching phenomenon.
elements.clean_text:
Detection of Solvent

Moreover, the sensing potential of 1 for different solvents was further explored. Various solvents including acetonitrile (CH3CN), N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), cyclohexane, N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), tetrahydrofuran (THF), methylbenzene, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), trichloromethane (CH3Cl), and nitrobenzene (NB) were used as the investigated reagents. The luminescence intensity of 1 is greatly dependent on the organic solvent, especially for NB, which appears as a significant species for luminescence quenching (a). Furthermore, the luminescence intensities were measured by the addition of NB into a suspension of 1 (dispersing 5 mg of 1 into 5 mL of water) to investigate the quenching effect of NB. As shown in b, with an increase in NB concentration from 0 to 0.6 ppm, the emission intensity of 1@aqueous solution decreases sharply with an emission color from bright blue to nearly black under UV light, which implies that compound 1 could act as an efficient luminescent sensor for NB. Decorated by an electron-withdrawing substituent -NO2 group, NB with a low LUMO energy is an excellent electron acceptor, which might drive the electrons from the ligand to the guest species, resulting in the luminescence quenching phenomenon.

elements.content: (a) Luminescent intensities of 1 in diverse solvents. (b) Emission spectra of an aqueous solutionof 1 with various amounts of nitrobenzene solvent.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Luminescent intensities of 1 in diverse solvents. (b) Emission spectra of an aqueous solutionof 1 with various amounts of nitrobenzene solvent.

elements.content: A dual-ligand strategy was utilized to construct two isostructural Zn–phosphonates by introducing a linear carboxylate as coligand. The diphosphonate with a bridged/chelated coordination mode plays a significant role in the formation of 2D Zn–HEDP layers, which are further connected through the deprotonated BPDC pillars. The Zn–phosphonate products both exhibit intense luminescent emission at room temperature. Notably, compound 1 shows remarkable luminescent sensing behavior toward different types of metal ions and solvents, revealing that it can be considered as a multiple probe for target analytes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A dual-ligand strategy was utilized to construct two isostructural Zn-phosphonates by introducing a linear carboxylate as coligand. The diphosphonate with a bridged/chelated coordination mode plays a significant role in the formation of 2D Zn-HEDP layers, which are further connected through the deprotonated BPDC pillars. The Zn-phosphonate products both exhibit intense luminescent emission at room temperature. Notably, compound 1 shows remarkable luminescent sensing behavior toward different types of metal ions and solvents, revealing that it can be considered as a multiple probe for target analytes.

cln_elements.content:
A 0.16 g portion of ZnO (1.0 mmol), 0.12 g of H2BPDC (0.5 mmol), 0.2 mL of HEDP (1.6 mmol), 0.2 mL of HF, 5 mL of H2O, and 5 mL of DMF were mixed in a Teflon-lined autoclave with a volume of 20 mL, and then the contents were heated and kept at 145 °C for 1 week. As the temperature was decreased to 30 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min, colorless X-ray-quality crystals could be acquired in 58% yield based on H2BPDC. Anal. Calcd for C11H22NO12P2Zn2 (552.97): C, 23.89; H, 4.01; N, 2.53. Found: C, 23.98; H, 4.06; N, 2.64. IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3386 (s), 3050 (s), 2797 (s), 2493 (m), 1600 (s), 1539 (m), 1401 (s), 1108 (s), 990 (s), 935 (m), 812 (w), 764 (m), 675 (w) (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[CH<sub>3</sub>NH<sub>3</sub>]­[Zn<sub>2</sub>(HEDP)­(BPDC)<sub>0.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·3.5H<sub>2</sub>O} (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of 0.16 g of ZnO (1.0 mmol), 0.12 g of H2BPDC (0.5 mmol), 0.15 mL of HEDP (1.2 mmol), 0.2 mL of HF, 10 mL of H2O, and 0.8 mL of methylamine was placed and sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave. The contents were heated to 80 °C, kept at that temperature for 1 week, and cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min, giving colorless block crystals. Yield: ca. 38% based on H2BPDC. Anal. Calcd for C10H25NO14.5P2Zn2 (583.99): C, 20.56; H, 4.31; N, 2.40. Found: C, 20.63; H, 4.19; N, 2.31. IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3394 (m), 2974 (m), 2878 (w), 1594 (s), 1416 (m), 1092 (s), 996 (w), 948 (w), 778 (w), 675 (w).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[(CH3)2NH2][Zn2(HEDP)(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]⋅H2O} (1)

A 0.16 g portion of ZnO (1.0 mmol), 0.12 g of H2BPDC (0.5 mmol), 0.2 mL of HEDP (1.6 mmol), 0.2 mL of HF, 5 mL of H2O, and 5 mL of DMF were mixed in a Teflon-lined autoclave with a volume of 20 mL, and then the contents were heated and kept at 145 °C for 1 week. As the temperature was decreased to 30 °C at a rate of 0.1 °C/min, colorless X-ray-quality crystals could be acquired in 58% yield based on H2BPDC. Anal. Calcd for C11H22NO12P2Zn2 (552.97): C, 23.89; H, 4.01; N, 2.53. Found: C, 23.98; H, 4.06; N, 2.64. IR (KBr pellets, cm-1): 3386 (s), 3050 (s), 2797 (s), 2493 (m), 1600 (s), 1539 (m), 1401 (s), 1108 (s), 990 (s), 935 (m), 812 (w), 764 (m), 675 (w) (Figure S2).

Synthesis of {[CH3NH3][Zn2(HEDP)(BPDC)0.5(H2O)2]⋅3.5H2O} (2)

A mixture of 0.16 g of ZnO (1.0 mmol), 0.12 g of H2BPDC (0.5 mmol), 0.15 mL of HEDP (1.2 mmol), 0.2 mL of HF, 10 mL of H2O, and 0.8 mL of methylamine was placed and sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave. The contents were heated to 80 °C, kept at that temperature for 1 week, and cooled to room temperature at a rate of 0.1 °C/min, giving colorless block crystals. Yield: ca. 38% based on H2BPDC. Anal. Calcd for C10H25NO14.5P2Zn2 (583.99): C, 20.56; H, 4.31; N, 2.40. Found: C, 20.63; H, 4.19; N, 2.31. IR (KBr pellets, cm-1): 3394 (m), 2974 (m), 2878 (w), 1594 (s), 1416 (m), 1092 (s), 996 (w), 948 (w), 778 (w), 675 (w).

metadata.title:
Multiple Detection Characteristics of Two Zinc Phosphonates:
Syntheses, Crystal Structures, and Luminescent Properties
